title: Six degrees of separation - Le Monde redesign
content:
• Le Monde newspaper was the brainchild of Gen Charles De Gaulle  
• The Billy Joel hit “We didn’t start the fire” contains the line “Charles De Gaulle, California baseball"  
• The California Angels baseball team, renamed the Anaheim Angels, renamed the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim were swept aside by the Boston Red Sox in the 2004 post-season on their way to their curse breaking World Series win.  
• The Boston Red Sox play at Fenway Park.  
• Matthew Carter designed "Fenway" for Sports Illustrated.  
• On Monday Le Monde’s [redesign hits the streets](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019191536/http:/www.thebusinessonline.com/Stories.aspx?Can%20redesign%20bring%20back%20readers?&StoryID=D53D860D-E1FA-4769-A2B9-B9DDAE691469&SectionID=D10E7723-CB86-485F-A420-D474F74D7E03) and uses, you guessed it, Fenway.
author: Si_Daniels

\>highly successful redesign

In other words, it didn't suck.  
Not quite as impressive as a f\*\*\*\*\*\* awesome redesign.  
I mean, how's it shape up against the new Grauniad?

\>\>highly successful redesign

\>In other words, it didn’t suck.

readership doesn't tank more than 5% + no more than 3000 letters of complaint = successful redesign

readership doesn't tank more than 2% + no more than 1000 letters of complaint = F'n successful redesign

readership increases + no more than 500 letters of complaint = cooking the books

I based my "highly successful" only on that paragraph, since of course  
I haven't seen the thing (which is why I asked that question). Maybe  
that claim is bogus, dunno. But I'm curious, does a redesign necessarily  
cause a readership drop? And what time period are we talking about?  
I mean, the guarantee of getting complaint letters is basically due  
to human nature, but don't we expect good design to bring increased  
readership, eventually? I thought Kevin was carried off in triumph  
in Helsinki.

BTW, what's a Grauniad?

hhp

The Grauniad is a (now largely affection) nickname for The Guardian, which used to be notorious for its misspellings. I don't think they still have the reputation, but the name has stuck.

The point of Kevin's presentation in Helsinki was about the relationship between the pleasurable aesthetic experience of typography and measurable increase in cognitive performance, based on related work in which people are found to perform problem solving tasks more easily and quickly after an enjoyable mental experience such as watching an amusing video rather than a dry lecture. So not directly related to the crapshoot of trying to increase readership in a competetive newspaper market.

I don't know about readership or circulation - but I've heard that whiney letters are a given whenever you redesign a paper.

Grow-nee-add is English slang for The Guardian.

And I thought it had something to do with groins.

To me the Guardian redesign, at least fontwise (I'm not qualified  
to judge it otherwise) was stellar - so I personally wouldn't use it  
as a reference point. Anyway it's more useful to compare papers that  
are in the same arena. And what's interesting here is that France  
is becoming more conservative (mostly in a bad way) so switching  
from de Groot's stuff\* to Fenway seems to make sense. Even though  
it's kinda sad too.

\* I mean the heads.

hhp

The Grauniad was first named that by the satirical magazine Private Eye in the '60s

Reading it daily after the redesign, I came to be really impressed with the typeface and the redesign, although there were a couple of things that bothered me (in the paper, not the face). They were outweighed by the brilliance, though.

At first, I didn't take to it, and I think that's why there are usually letters from readers who don't like their habits disrupted.

That and people as a rule go out of their way more to complain than to praise.

hhp

Fenway is in the back bay neighbourhood formally called Kenmore. The Fens is an area about a mile south of Fenway Park.

The Fens is a Lincolnshire area with the towns Boston and Spalding in eastern coastal England.

A.G. Spalding was a Boston Red Sox pitcher who founded the Spalding athletic company in 1876.

I was born 8/10 of a mile from Fenway Park in what is now the Beth Isreal Deaconess Medical Center, the official hospital of the Boston Red Sox. I now live in London England.

Matthew Carter was born in England, but lives in Cambridge (MA) across the Charles River from Fenway Park.

We both made bitmaps for Tahoma, he on a Mac and me on Windows.

Utopia and something else by Slimbach. Vraiment ennuyant.
